awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Growing up STEM: An Interdisciplinary Research Experience in Undergraduate STEM Education
awd_abstract_narration:
To enhance learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), we need to better understand how students acquire and use STEM knowledge, and how instructors can help students learn. Discipline-based education researchers (DBERs) contribute to this understanding by applying their STEM expertise to the study of teaching and learning. DBER is a relatively young field and we need to train more scholars to do this important research. This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at North Dakota State University (NDSU) will address this need by hosting a summer program that will engage 30 undergraduate students in conducting discipline-based education research in science and mathematics.

Through this REU Site, the student participants will select from a wide variety of research projects that pose important questions about the nature of teaching and learning in STEM. The interdisciplinary team of faculty mentors provides a diverse set of projects across the disciplines of biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics and psychology. This diversity in research exposes REU participants to nearly a dozen other projects to enrich their experience with and understanding of the breadth of investigations conducted in DBER. Students will jump-start their research experience through online interactions with their mentors, including reading and discussing relevant research papers. The benefits of this early, virtual mentoring will be two-fold: students receive essential training in education research and begin to develop relationships with their research mentors prior to arriving on campus. Once they arrive at NDSU, the REU fellows will participate in a learning community that includes cohort-building activities, as well as both faculty and peer mentoring to support their research activities. REU students will also participate in a well-structured professional development series in which they will learn about ethical practices; research methods; scientific communication and presentation skills; pathways to graduate school; and careers in STEM. Students will present their research and results through informal chalk talks in the first half of the program and then more formally at a capstone poster symposium at the end of the summer. In addition to summative evaluation, the project team will implement continuous formative evaluation to provide feedback that helps them refine and improve the REU Site each year. Student entrance and exit surveys, student interviews, faculty surveys, and alumni follow-up surveys will provide essential data for continuous program improvement. Overall, this REU Site will build the discipline-based education research talent pool and contribute to improvements in undergraduate STEM education.

The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in areas of research funded by NSF. This REU project is supported by NSF's Education & Human Resources Directorate Core Research (ECR) Program and its Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Growing Up STEM, hosted by North Dakota State University, is one of the first NSF-supported interdisciplinary REU programs focused on introducing undergraduates to research in Discipline-Based Education Research (DBER). Our program seeks to develop the whole student, supporting development of research and professional skills, while attending to the health and well-being of all participants. In particular, our program goals included:

  1. Providing participants an authentic experience in DBER to facilitate informed decisions regarding career pathways and opportunities in DBER.
  2. Enabling participants to develop hands-on and critical thinking skills to facilitate their engagement and future success in research.
  3. Fostering an understanding and appreciation of the collaborative and collegial nature of research through participation in a collaborative research environment.
  4. Encouraging participants to evaluate the implications of DBER research on teaching and learning in the undergraduate classroom.
  5. Increasing participants’ science communication skills through dissemination of research via posters and oral presentations at local, regional, and national conferences.

Across all years of our REU program, we supported 40 REU participants who developed and implemented independent research projects. Participants were mentored by 11 DBER and affiliated faculty across disciplines of Biology, Chemistry and Biochemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, Geosciences and Physics. Faculty mentors across the four summers included: Kimi Booth (Biological Sciences), John Buncher (Physics), Warren Christensen (Physics), Danielle Condry (Microbiological Sciences), Stephanie Day (Geosciences), Alexey Leontyev (Chemistry), Jenni Momsen (Biological Sciences), Lisa Montplaisir (Biological sciences), James Nyachwaya (Chemistry), Gursimran Walia (Computer Science), and Katie Wissman (Psychology).


A primary goal of Growing Up STEM was to support participants’ development of research, communication, and professional skills. Each week, REU students participated in a series of workshops centered on these skills (e.g., morning methods workshop series; sci comm workshop series). Specific research skill development occurred through individual meetings with mentors, lab meetings, and small-group discussions. Finally, students gained practical experiences through chalk talks and our end-of-program poster symposium.


A second goal of Growing Up STEM was to support the development of a community of practice, so that students felt included in our broader DBER community. We accomplished this goal by supporting the development of a cohort of scholars, who were housed together in campus apartments, worked in communal research spaces, and participated in organized social activities. REU participants were actively engaged in weekly lab meetings, which provided opportunities to develop analytical and presentation skills, alongside graduate students and postdocs. Outside of research, REU participants took part in a number of social events led by faculty, including a rib cooking festival, a local baseball game, a welcoming picnic, downtown street fair, and an end of program farewell BBQ.


The success of our program is measured by the success of our participants. Over the course of our program, 16 REU participants presented their research at national meetings, with two students earning awards for their posters. Five students published a portion of their summer research, and one student was awarded an NSF GRFP while another student earned an Honorable Mention.
